importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The US began a series of strikes in the Caribbean starting in September 2025, marking the beginning of a large-scale counter-narcotics military operation.
The date of the article's publication, indicating the most recent update on the US military operations and the release of survivors from a Caribbean strike.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September 2025 to October 2025 represents the timeframe during which the US military has conducted multiple strikes on suspected drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean, resulting in casualties and international controversy.

keyTakeAways: The US military has launched a series of strikes in the Caribbean, targeting vessels believed to be involved in drug smuggling, with at least 32 people killed across seven attacks since September 2025.

Two survivors—Andrés Fernando Tufiño (Ecuadorian) and Jeison Obando Pérez (Colombian)—were rescued and repatriated after the strike on a semi-submersible vessel, which US officials claim was a drug-carrying submarine loaded with fentanyl and other narcotics.

Ecuadorean authorities stated there was no legal basis to detain Tufiño due to a lack of criminal evidence, while the Colombian survivor sustained a traumatic brain injury and requires medical treatment.

The US administration, led by President Donald Trump, asserts the operations target 'narco-terrorists' and claims the vessel was specifically built for drug transport, though experts question the legality and origin of the narcotics under international law.

The operations have been criticized by regional leaders, including Colombian President Gustavo Petro, who accused the US of violating Colombian territorial waters and calling the strike a murder, and by Trinidad and Tobago’s media, which raised concerns about local nationals killed.

The US has accused Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro of running a drug trafficking group known as the Cartel of the Suns, a claim Maduro denies and which has prompted US covert operations in Venezuela.

The US has deployed around 10,000 troops, military aircraft, and ships to the region as part of its counter-narcotics campaign, signaling a significant escalation in military presence in the Caribbean.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Ecuador has released Andrés Fernando Tufiño, a survivor of a US military strike on a semi-submersible vessel in the Caribbean allegedly used for drug smuggling, after the Ecuadorean Attorney General’s office found no criminal evidence against him. The US, under President Donald Trump, claims the vessel was carrying fentanyl and was a drug-carrying submarine built specifically for narcotics transport, though experts question the legality and origin of the drugs. The operation, which began in September 2025, has resulted in at least 32 deaths across seven strikes and has drawn international criticism, including from Colombian President Gustavo Petro, who accused the US of violating Colombian territorial waters. The US has accused Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro of running the Cartel of the Suns, a drug trafficking group, and has intensified pressure on Venezuela through covert operations. The two survivors—Tufiño and Jeison Obando Pérez—are the first known to survive such attacks, with the Colombian survivor suffering a serious injury. The operation involves a massive US military deployment, including around 10,000 troops and numerous aircraft and ships, and has sparked regional debate over sovereignty, legality, and the humanitarian impact of military interventions.
title: Ecuador releases survivor of US strike on 'drug sub' in Caribbean
